documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>African-American sheet music, 1850-1920 selected from the collection of Brown University.</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>African Americans--Music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Minstrel music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Songs and music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Popular music--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Music--United States--19th century.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Music--United States--20th century.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>sheet music; African-American</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Selected from the Sheet Music Collection at the John Hay Library at Brown University. Consists of 1,305 pieces of American-American sheet music dating from 1850 through 1920. Includes many songs from the heyday of antebellum black face minstrelsy in the 1850s and from the abolitionist movement of the same period. Numerous titles are associated with the novel and the play Uncle Tom's Cabin. Civil War period music includes songs about African-American soldiers and the plight of the newly emancipated slave. Post-Civil War music reflects the problems of Reconstruction and the beginnings of urbanization and the northern migration of African Americans. African-American popular composers include James Bland, Ernest Hogan, Bob Cole, James Reese Europe, and Will Marion Cook.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Copyright and other restrictions: Permission to copy in any form or to publish material from the Collection must be obtained from Brown University Library.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Nov. 9, 1999.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress, American Memory</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>1999-</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000019</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:creator>American Folklife Center.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Omaha Indians--Music--History and criticism.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Folk music--Nebraska--History and criticism.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Omaha Indians--Music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Folk music--Nebraska.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Ethnographic field collection of traditional Omaha music from the 1890s through the 1980s. Contains recordings from wax cylinders, songs, speeches, interviews, photographs, field notes, and tape logs. Features material from the 1983 Omaha harvest celebration pow-wow, 1985 Hethu'shka Society concert at the Library of Congress, and 1983 and 1999 interviews with members of the Omaha tribe.</dc:description>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Florida Folklife from the WPA Collections 1937-1942</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Kennedy, Stetson.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>American Folklife Center.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Folklore--Florida.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Florida--Social life and customs.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Florida Folklife from the WPA Collections is a multiformat ethnographic field collection documenting African-American,  Arabic, Bahamian, British-American, Cuban, Greek, Italian, Minorcan, Seminole, and Slavic cultures throughout Florida. Features folksongs and folktales in many languages, including blues and work songs from menhaden fishing boats, railroad gangs, and turpentine camps; children's songs, dance music, and religious music of many cultures; and interviews, also known as life histories. Provides access to 376 sound recordings and 106 accompanying materials, personnel. Includes a special presentation, A Florida treasure hunt, by Stetson Kennedy. Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on 08-16-00.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Proposed recording expedition into the Floridas / by Zora Neale Hurston -- Map of Florida (from the General Maps Collection) -- Ethnic and cultural groups -- Bibliography -- Related resources.</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2000-</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/collafc.af000008</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Florida</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Prairie settlement Nebraska photographs and family letters, 1862-1912.</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Butcher, Solomon D. (Solomon Devore), 1856-1927.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Nebraska State Historical Society.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Frontier and pioneer life--Nebraska--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Land settlement--Nebraska--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Oblinger family--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Nebraska--Pictorial works.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Nebraska--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Nebraska--Social life and customs--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Fillmore County (Neb.)--Biography.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>This digital collection integrates two collections from the holdings of the Nebraska State Historical Society, which illustrate the story of settlement on the Great Plains. Includes approximately 3,000 glass plate negatives by Solomon D. Butcher which record the process of settlement of Nebraska between 1886 and 1912, including Custer, Buffalo, Dawson, and Cherry counties. Also includes approximately 3,000 pages of Oblinger family letters discussing land, work, neighbors, crops, religious meetings, problems with grasshoppers, financial problems, and the Easter Blizzard of 1873. Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Aug. 22, 2000.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2000-</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000020</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Nebraska</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Fillmore County (Neb.)</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Puerto Rico at the dawn of the modern age nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century perspectives ; from selected divisions of the Library of Congress.</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Hispanic Division.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Spanish-American War, 1898--Personal narratives.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Puerto Rico--History--19th century.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Puerto Rico--History--20th century.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Puerto Rico--Politics and government.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Puerto Rico--Description and travel.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Portrays the early history of the commonwealth of Puerto Rico through first-person accounts, political writings, and histories drawn from the Library of Congress's General Collections. Among the topics it highlights are the land and its resources, relations with Spain, the competition among political parties, reform efforts, and recollections by veterans of the Spanish-American War. Materials in the collection were published between 1831 and 1929 and consist of thirty-nine political pamphlets, eighteen monographs, and one journal.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Apr. 4, 2000.</dc:description>
<dc:description>A collaborative project of the Library of Congress Hispanic Division and the National Digital Library Program in recognition of the centennial of the Spanish-American War.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Selected from the collections of the Library of Congress's Humanities and Social Sciences Division, General Collection, Hispanic Division, and Geography and Map Division.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource.</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>[20]00-</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000033</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Puerto Rico</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:creator>Work, John W. (John Wesley), 1901-1967.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Jones, Lewis Wade, 1910-1979.</dc:creator>

<dc:description>Consists of sound recordings, primarily blues and gospel songs, and related documentation created by John Wesley Work III in 1941 and by Lewis Jones and Willis Laurence James in March, June, and July 1943 at the folk festival at Fort Valley College (now Fort Valley State University), Fort Valley, Georgia.  Also included are recordings made in Tennessee and Alabama (including six Sacred Harp songs) by John Work.</dc:description>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Quilts and quiltmaking in America, 1978-1996</dc:title>
<dc:creator>American Folklife Center.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Quilts--Blue Ridge Mountains--Catalogs.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Quilts--United States--Catalogs.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Folk art--Blue Ridge Mountains--Catalogs.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Folk art--United States--Catalogs.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Quiltmakers--Blue Ridge Mountains--Interviews.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Blue Ridge Parkway Folklife Project.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Lands' End All-American Quilt Contest.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Showcases materials from two American Folklife Center collections, the Blue Ridge Parkway Folklife Project Collection (1978) and the "All-American Quilt Contest" sponsored by Coming Home, a division of Lands' End, and Good Housekeeping. Together these collections provide a glimpse into America's diverse quilting traditions. The quilt documentation from the Blue Ridge Parkway Folklife Project, an ethnographic field project conducted by the American Folklife Center in cooperation with the National Park Service, includes over 220 photographs and over 180 recorded interviews with quiltmakers in Appalachian North  Carolina and Virginia. These materials document quilts and quilting within the context of daily life and reflect a range of backgrounds, motivations, and aesthetic sensibilities. The materials presented from the Lands' End All-American Quilt Contest collection include images of approximately 180 winning quilts from across the United States. The collection represents a wide range of quiltmaking, from highly traditional to innovative, and the quilts pictured exhibit excellent design and technical skill in a variety of styles and materials.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Aug. 17, 2000.</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : American Folklife Center, Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>1999-</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/collafc.af000010</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Historic American sheet music, 1850-1920 selected from the collections of Duke University.</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Miller, Stephen D. (Stephen Douglas), 1971-</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Schultz, Lois, 1944-</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Duke University. Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Music--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>African Americans--Music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Music publishers--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Music publishing--United States--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Popular music--To 1901.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Popular music--1901-1910.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Popular music--1911-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Dance music--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Instrumental music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Songs with piano.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Operas--Excerpts.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>World War, 1914-1918--Songs and music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Patriotic music--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Confederate States of America--Songs and music.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1865--Songs and music.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Digital images of 3042 pieces of sheet music published in the United States between 1850 and 1920 selected from the collections in the Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library, Duke University. The selection presents a significant perspective on American history and culture. The sheet music chosen for digital reproduction represents a wide variety of music types including bel canto, minstrel songs, protest songs, sentimental songs, patriotic and political songs, plantation songs, Civil War songs, spirituals, dance music, songs from vaudeville and musicals, "Tin pan alley" songs, and songs from World War I. The collection is particularly strong in antebellum Southern music, Confederate imprints, and Civil war songs. Piano music includes marches, variations, opera excerpts, and dance music (waltzes, quadrilles, polkas, etc.)</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on June 2, 2000.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>1999-</dc:date>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000022</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Confederate States of America</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>United States</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:title>Origins of American animation</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Animation (Cinematography)--United States--History--20th century.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Motion pictures--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"The development of early American animation is represented by this collection of 21 animated films and 2 fragments, which spans the years 1900 to 1921. The films include clay, puppet, and cut-out animation, as well as pen drawings. They point to a connection between newspaper comic strips and early animated films, as represented by Keeping Up With the Joneses, Krazy Kat, and The Katzenjammer Kids. As well as showing the development of animation, these films also reveal the social attitudes of early twentieth-century America."</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from opening screen (viewed June 29, 1999)</dc:description>
<dc:description>Text (HTML), digital images</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>Washington, D.C. : Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division, Library of Congress</dc:publisher>

<dc:language>eng</dc:language>

<dc:title>Band music from the Civil War era</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Music Division.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Brass band music--Scores and parts.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Brass band music--19th century.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Makes available examples of a brilliant style of brass band music that flourished in the 1850s in the United States and remained popular through the nineteenth century. Bands of this kind served in the armies of both the North and the South during the Civil War. This online collection includes both printed and manuscript music selected from the collections of the Music Division of the Library of Congress and the Walter Dignam Collection of the  Manchester Historic Association (Manchester, New Hampshire). The collection features over 700 musical compositions, as well as 8 full-score modern editions and 19 recorded examples of brass band music in performance."</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from opening screen.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Description based on page viewed 08-14-2000.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"American Memory, Library of Congress".</dc:description>

<dc:date>2000-</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.music/collmus.mu000008</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:title>"I do solemnly swear--", presidential inaugurations from several divisions of the Library of Congress and other institutions.</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Presidents--United States--Inauguration--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Inauguration Day--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Presidents--United States--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Washington (D.C.)--Social life and customs.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>A collection of items or digital files from each of the 62 inaugurations from George Washington's in 1789 to William Jefferson Clinton's in 1997, and will include items from the 63rd inauguration of 2001. This presentation includes diaries and letters of presidents and of those who witnessed inaugurations, handwritten drafts of inaugural addresses, broadsides, inaugural tickets and programs, prints, photographs, and sheet music. An important component is the collaboration with the Avalon Project at the Yale Law School, which permits the site to offer Yale's online presentations of the inaugural addresses from Presidents Washington to Bush with associated searchable text transcriptions.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Nov. 8, 2000.</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2000-</dc:date>

<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Washington (D.C.)</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Wright brothers glass-plate negative collection</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Wright, Orville, 1871-1948, photographer.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Wright, Wilbur, 1867-1912, photographer.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Wright, Wilbur,--1867-1912.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Wright, Orville,--1871-1948.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Wright, Wilbur,--1867-1912--Friends & associates.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Wright, Orville,--1871-1948--Friends & associates.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Wright family.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Aeronautics--United States--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Flight testing--North Carolina--Kitty Hawk--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Flight testing--Ohio--Dayton--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Gliders--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Airplanes--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Families--Ohio--Dayton--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Pets--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Dogs--1890-1930.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Subjects depicted include portraits of the Wright brothers and their family members; friends and associates; views of the Wright family home at 7 Hawthorn St., Dayton, Ohio; Orville Wright's home "Hawthorne Hill", Dayton; family gatherings; the brothers performing gliding experiments and powered flight tests at Kitty Hawk, N.C., and at Huffman Prairie, Dayton, Ohio, (including views of the first flight at Kitty Hawk, Dec. 17, 1903).  Also includes images of the Wright camp at Kitty Hawk; airplane motors; a few views of the Wright Company plant; portraits of Orville Wright's dog Scipio; some landscape views of areas around Dayton, Ohio, and Kitty Hawk, N.C.  Also, Charles Lindbergh at Wilbur Wright Field, 1927; photographs of documents relating to a legal case against Bishop Milton Wright.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Use the digital versions to preserve the fragile original negatives.</dc:description>
<dc:description>LOT title devised by Library staff.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Negatives are assigned the following filing series designations: LC-W85 (for 4x5 in.) and LC-W86 (for 5x7 in. and nitrate)</dc:description>
<dc:description>Orville and Wilbur Wright, pioneers in early aviation,  used photography to document their experiments with flight.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Transfer; Science and Technology Division; 1962.</dc:description>
<dc:description>A set of catalog records describing each item is available through the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting. See http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/lcoa1.about</dc:description>
<dc:description>Forms part of: The Papers of Wilbur and Orville Wright.</dc:description>
<dc:date>1897-1928, bulk 1898-1911</dc:date>
<dc:type>image</dc:type>
<dc:type>still image</dc:type>
<dc:type>Portrait photographs</dc:type>
<dc:type>Group portraits</dc:type>
<dc:type>Landscape photographs</dc:type>
<dc:type>Glass negatives</dc:type>
<dc:type>Nitrate negatives</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.wri</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:rights>Publication of some images may be restricted. For information see "Photographs taken by the Wright Brothers (LOT 11512)," [http://www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/269_wri.html]</dc:rights>
</oai_dc:dc>

Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>

<dc:subject>Washington Region--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Washington Region--Biography.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Presents books that capture the Washington, D.C. area and Chesapeake Bay region in words and pictures. Depicts the region as it developed between the onset of European settlement and the first quarter of the twentieth century. Selected from the Library of Congress's general collections and its Rare Book and Special Collections Division, the collection offers first-person narratives, early histories, historical biographies, promotional brochures, and books of photographs.</dc:description>

<dc:title>Chicago anarchists on trial</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Chicago Historical Society.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Haymarket Square Riot, Chicago, Ill., 1886--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Presents more than 3,800 images of original manuscripts, broadsides, photographs, prints, and artifacts relating to the Haymarket Affair, a violent confrontation between Chicago police and labor protesters in 1886. Covers the May 4, 1886 meeting and bombing; the trial, conviction, and subsequent appeals of those accused of inciting the bombing; and the execution of four of the convicted and the later pardon of the remaining defendants. Features searchable transcript of the murder trial. Includes twenty-four images of three-dimensional artifacts, including contemporary Chicago Police Department paraphernalia, labor banners, and an unexploded bomb casing.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on May 8, 2001.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>The Haymarket affair narrative -- Haymarket affair chronology -- The Haymarket affair evidence -- About the collection.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>[2001]-</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000006</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Rare Book and Special Collections Division.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Printed Ephemera Collection (Library of Congress)</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Printed ephemera--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>United States--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Derived from the Printed Ephemera Collection at the Library of Congress, presents thousands of primary source items from the American states, the District of Columbia, and London, England. Materials date from the seventeenth century to the present and encompass key events and eras in American history such as the American Revolution, slavery, the western land rush, the American Civil War, women's suffrage, and the Industrial Revolution. Features posters, notices, advertisements, proclamations, leaflets, propaganda, manifestos, and business cards.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on May 9, 2001.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Introduction to printed ephemera collection -- About the collection -- Glossary -- Page order and folding diagrams.</dc:description>

<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/collrbc.rb000002</dc:identifier>

<dc:title>Sunday school books shaping the values of youth in nineteenth-century America /</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Michigan State University. Libraries.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Clarke Historical Library.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Sunday school literature.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Religious literature, American.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Presents 163 Sunday school books published in America between 1815 and 1865. Drawn from the collections of Michigan State University Libraries and the Clarke Historical Library at Central Michigan University Libraries, documents the culture of religious instruction of youth in America during the antebellum era. Individual works illustrate a number of thematic divisions that preoccupied nineteenth-century America such as sacred and secular, natural and divine, civilized and savage, rural and industrial, and adult and child. Topics include history, holidays, slavery, African Americans, Native Americans, travel and missionary accounts, death and dying, poverty, temperance, immigrants, and advice.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on July 13, 2001.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Author biographies -- About the collection -- Shaping the values of youth : essay -- Building the digital collection.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2001-</dc:date>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000008</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:description>The Fred Hulstrand History in Pictures Collection and The F.A. Pazandak Photograph Collection, two collections from the Institute for Regional Studies at the North Dakota State University, depict rural and small-town life at the turn of the century. Resource features images of sod homes and the people who built them; farms and the machinery that made them prosper; and one-room schools and the children that were educated in them. Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>

<dc:description>"This digital collection integrates over 2,300 photographs and 7,700 pages of text relating to the American Indians in two cultural areas of the Pacific Northwest, the Northwest Coast and Plateau. These resources illustrate many aspects of life and work, including housing, clothing, crafts, transportation, education, and employment. The materials are drawn from the extensive collections of the University of Washington Libraries, the Cheney Cowles Museum/Eastern Washington State Historical Society in Spokane, and the Museum of History and Industry in Seattle."</dc:description>

<dc:description>Features sixty-eight motion pictures produced between 1898 and 1901 of the Spanish-American War and the subsequent Philippine Revolution. Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Brumfield photograph collection</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Brumfield, William Craft, 1944- photographer, donor.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Architecture--Russia (Federation)--1980-2000.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Churches--Russia (Federation)--1980-2000.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Monasteries--Russia (Federation)--1980-2000.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Cathedrals--Russia (Federation)--1980-2000.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Log buildings--Russia (Federation)--1980-2000.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Architectural decorations & ornaments--Russia (Federation)--1980-2000.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>The photographs document the architecture of pre-Soviet Russia. Most of the structures are churches, cathedrals, and monasteries, often shown in multiple views. Structures are located in both large cities and small towns from west of the Ural Mountains eastward through Siberia. Interior views include icon screens (iconostases) and fresco murals. Also represented are dwellings, commercial, and log buildings along with a few views of meadows, lakes, rivers and trees.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Collection title devised by library staff.</dc:description>
<dc:description>For reference access, please use the digital image surrogates in the online catalog to preserve the fragile original items</dc:description>
<dc:description>Brumfield took most of these photographs for his research and teaching as a Professor of Slavic Studies at Tulane University and as a lecturer at the School of Architecture, museums, and universities in North America and Europe. Several hundred of the slides were taken especially for the Library of Congress project "Meeting of Frontiers" on three  trips to Russia in 1999 and 2000.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Gift; William C. Brumfield 2000 (DLC/PP-2000:047)</dc:description>
<dc:description>Gift; William C. Brumfield 2000 (DLC/PP-2000:050)</dc:description>
<dc:description>A set of catalog records describing each item is available through the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting. See http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/lcoa1.about</dc:description>
<dc:date>1987-2000</dc:date>
<dc:type>image</dc:type>
<dc:type>still image</dc:type>
<dc:type>collection</dc:type>
<dc:type>Architectural photographs</dc:type>
<dc:type>Slides</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.brum</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:rights>Publication may be restricted. For information see Brumfield Photograph Collection rights statement, [http://lcweb.loc.gov/rr/print/res/238_brum.html]</dc:rights>
</oai_dc:dc>

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Adams photographs of Manzanar War Relocation Center</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Adams, Ansel, 1902-1984, photographer.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Manzanar War Relocation Center--1940-1950.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>World War, 1939-1945--Japanese Americans--California--Manzanar.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Japanese Americans--California--Manzanar--1940-1950.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Concentration camps--California--Manzanar--1940-1950</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Photographs document the lives of Japanese Americans interned during World War II at the Manzanar Relocation Center, in Inyo County, California. There are numerous close-up and occupational portraits of individuals, including Roy Takeno, editor of the Manzanar Free Press, and photographer Tōyō Miyatake.  Group portraits include families, women and children. Other photographs show people posed in their living quarters and engaged in indoor daily life such as shopping, religious services, health care, and education; more informal views portray outdoor agricultural scenes and sports and leisure activities. Landscape views feature the background mountains and desert as well as camp facilities and buildings.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Collection title devised by Library staff.</dc:description>
<dc:description>There are 244 distinct images. Most are represented by a pair of negatives and prints; 2 are represented only by prints; and 36 are represented only by negatives.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Restricted access. Please use digital and print surrogates to preserve the fragile original prints and negatives.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Well-known fine art and landscape photographer, Ansel Adams, took on several war-related assignments. When offering the Manzanar photos to the Library in 1965, Adams wrote in an accompanying letter, "The purpose of my work was to show how these people, suffering under a great injustice ... had overcome the sense of defeat and dispair [sic] by building for themselves a vital community in an arid (but magnificent) environment."</dc:description>
<dc:description>Some photographs published in Born free and equal : photographs of the loyal Japanese-Americans at Manzanar Relocation Center, Inyo County, California / by Ansel Adams. New York : U.S. Camera, 1944.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Gift; Ansel Adams; 1965-1968.</dc:description>
<dc:description>A set of catalog records describing each item is available through the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting. See http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/lcoa1.about</dc:description>
<dc:date>1943</dc:date>

<dc:type>Group portraits</dc:type>

<dc:type>Nitrate negatives</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.manz</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:rights>No known restrictions on publication.</dc:rights>
</oai_dc:dc>

keys: Raglan, FitzRoy James Henry Somerset,--Baron,--1788-1855--Military service.
documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Fenton Crimean War photograph collection</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Fenton, Roger, 1819-1869, photographer.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Fenton, Roger,--1819-1869--Journeys--Ukraine--Crimea.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Raglan, FitzRoy James Henry Somerset,--Baron,--1788-1855--Military service.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Pélissier, Aimable-Jean-Jacques,--duc de Malakoff,--1794-1864--Military service.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Ömer Lûtfi Paşa,--1806-1871--Military service.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Crimean War, 1853-1856.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Military personnel--Ukraine--Crimea--1850-1860.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Military life--Ukraine--Crimea--1850-1860.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Balaklava (Ukraine)--1850-1860.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Sevastopolʹ (Ukraine)--History--Siege, 1854-1855.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>These photographs present a substantial documentary record of the participants and the landscape of the Crimean War, although there are no actual combat scenes. Comprised mainly of portrait photographs of British military personnel, as well as some French and Turkish military personnel, including a nurse attached to the French troops, leaders of the allied forces, Lord Raglan, Maréchal Pélissier, and Ömer Lûtfi Paşa, and Fenton dressed as a Zouave. The views show cavalry and artillery camps, a mortar battery, a cemetery; buildings, the harbor, and ships at Balaklava; the plains between Balaklava and Sevastopolʹ, and distant views of Sevastopolʹ.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Collection title devised by Library staff.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Restricted access: Materials extremely fragile; Served by appointment only.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Guide to the Special Collections of Prints & Photographs in the Library of Congress / compiled by Paul Vanderbilt. Washington, D.C. : 1955, no. 230</dc:description>
<dc:description>Special Collections in the Library of Congress / compiled by Annette Melville. Washington, D.C. : Library of Congress, 1980, no. 80</dc:description>
<dc:description>Roger Fenton (1819-1869) began experimenting with photography ca. 1851 and continued until 1862. His Crimean War photographs represent one of the earliest systematic attempts to document a war through the medium of photography. Although Fenton spent fewer than four months in the Crimea (March 8 to June 26, 1855), he produced 360 photographs under extremely trying conditions for publication by Thomas Agnew & Sons which began to issue sets of photographs in November of 1855. The Library's collection of 263 unpublished photos is possibly a set of prints kept and annotated by Fenton himself.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Collection profile with information about Fenton's career, the Crimean War, and a bibliography is available online http://lcweb.loc.gov/rr/print/coll/251_fen.html</dc:description>
<dc:description>A set of catalog records describing each item is available through the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting. See http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/lcoa1.about</dc:description>
<dc:description>Purchase; Frances M. Fenton; 1944; (DLC/PP-1945:117).</dc:description>
<dc:description>Roger Fenton, photographer of the Crimean War: His photographs and his letters from the Crimea, with an essay on his life and work by Helmut and Alison Gernsheim. London : Secker & Warburg, 1954.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Roger Fenton, photographer of the 1850s : Hayward Gallery, London, 4 February to 17 April 1988. [London] : South Bank Board, c1988.</dc:description>
<dc:date>1855</dc:date>
<dc:type>image</dc:type>
<dc:type>still image</dc:type>
<dc:type>collection</dc:type>
<dc:type>Portrait photographs</dc:type>
<dc:type>Group portraits</dc:type>
<dc:type>Salted paper prints</dc:type>
<dc:type>Albumen prints</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.ftncnw</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Balaklava (Ukraine)</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Sevastopolʹ (Ukraine)</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:subject>Bahamas--1890-1910.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Photochrom prints show late 19th and early 20th century travel views of Europe and the Middle East, primarily of Eastern and Central European destinations (including the former Austro-Hungarian Empire).  Includes cities and towns in Austria, Belgium, Bosnia & Hercegovina, Croatia, the Czeck Republic, Denmark, England, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, Montenegro, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, the French and Italian Riviera, Romania, Russia, Scotland, Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Syria, Ukraine, and Wales. Also includes some views of sites in Algeria, the Holy Land, Tunisia, and Turkey. Also depicted are many views of the United States, Cuba, the Bahamas, and Canada with extensive coverage of Colorado, California, New York, Utah, Florida, Washington, DC, and other states. Images primarily depict architecture, monuments, landscapes, cityscapes, and waterfronts. Some images also show people and aspects of daily life.  Also includes one group of unidentified views.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Prints bear English, French, German, and Russian captions.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Item numbers and the initials "P.Z." [i.e., Photoglob Zurich] appear on most prints.</dc:description>
<dc:description>The original prints are fragile; please use the online digital images.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Catalogue F. Scenic, Architectural, and Marine Views / Detroit Photographic Co. Detroit, Mich. : Detroit Photographic Co., c1899.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Catalogue J. Foreign Section / Detroit Publishing Co. Detroit, Mich. : Detroit Publishing Co., c1905.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Collection title devised by Library staff.</dc:description>
<dc:description>More information about the Photochrom Print Collection is available at http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.pgz</dc:description>
<dc:description>Finding aid: Annotated copies of pages in the Detroit Publishing Company sales catalogs provide a contents list for most LOTs. Available in the Prints & Photographs Reading Room, filed under collection name.</dc:description>

<dc:description>3076-1: Ox teams in the Black Hills of South Dakota; 3076-2: Portraits of Oglala, Lakota, Miniconjou, and Brulé Indians, Pine Ridge and Cheyenne River, South Dakota; 3076-3: Railroads, including construction and railroad camps in South Dakota and Wyoming; 3076-4: Portraits of U.S. Cavalry & Infantry at South Dakota; 3076-5: Parades at Deadwood, South Dakota and Chicago, Ill.; 3076-6: Cityscapes and commercial buildings in South Dakota and Colorado; 3076-7: Ranch houses and a log cabin in South Dakota; 3076-8: Stagecoaches and coach drivers, including the Last Deadwood coach and Wells Fargo Express Co.; 3076-9: Military facilities at Fort Meade and Pine Ridge, South Dakota; 3076-10: Lumber mills in South Dakota; 3076-11: Portraits of Indians with U.S. officials at Pine Ridge, South Dakota; 3076-12: Cowboys, roundups, & branding at Belle Fourche, South Dakota and other locations; 3076-13: Portraits of hunters; 3076-14: Devil's Tower National Monument and "Little Missouri butte"; 3076-15: Landscapes, buttes, and rock formations in the Black Hills of South Dakota and Wyo.; 3076-16: Prospectors; 3076-17: Mines & mining activities, South Dakota; 3076-18: Chinese immigrant "hose team" and the burial of a Chinese immigrant, Deadwood, S.D.; 3076-19: Beef issue to Lakota Indians, Pine Ridge, South Dakota; 3076-20: Sheep herding, South Dakota; 3076-21: Miscellaneous.</dc:description>

<dc:title>Westward by sea a maritime perspective on American expansion, 1820-1890 /</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Mystic Seaport Museum.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Voyages to the Pacific Coast--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Seafaring life--United States--History--19th century--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>United States--Territorial expansion--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"This selection of items from Mystic Seaport's archival collections includes logbooks, diaries, letters, business papers, and published narratives of voyages and travels. The unique maritime perspective of these materials offers a rich look at the events, culture, beliefs, and personal experiences associated with the settlement of California, Alaska, Hawaii, Texas, and the Pacific Northwest. A number of photographs, paintings, maps, and nautical charts are also included to illustrate the story of Americans' western seaborne travel. Various themes are touched upon, including whaling, life at sea, shipping, women at sea, and native populations."--Home page.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Mar. 15, 2002.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2002</dc:date>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000012</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>United States</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>The church in the southern Black community, 1780-1925</dc:title>
<dc:creator>University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>African Americans--Southern States--Religion.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>African American churches--Southern States--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Slavery and the church--Southern States--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Southern States--Church history.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Southern States--Social life and customs.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"This compilation of printed texts from the libraries at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill traces how Southern African Americans experienced and transformed Protestant Christianity into the central institution of community life. Coverage begins with white churches' conversion efforts, especially in the post-Revolutionary period, and depicts the tensions and contradictions between the egalitarian potential of evangelical Christianity and the realities of slavery. It focuses, through slave narratives and observations by other African American authors, on how the black community adapted evangelical Christianity, making it a metaphor for freedom, community, and personal survival. An award from the Library of Congress/Ameritech National Digital Library Competition supported the digitization of 100 titles. The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill supplemented these titles with thirty-five additional texts illuminating the same theme."--Home page.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Mar. 19, 2002.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>[Washington, D.C.] : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2001</dc:date>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000013</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Southern States</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:title>History of the American West, 1860-1920</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Denver Public Library. Western History/Genealogy Dept.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>West (U.S.)--History--1860-1890--Pictorial works.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>West (U.S.)--History--1890-1945--Pictorial works.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Colorado--History--Pictorial works.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"Over 30,000 photographs, drawn from the holdings of the Western History and Genealogy Department at Denver Public Library, illuminate many aspects of the history of the American West. Most of the photographs were taken between 1860 and 1920. They illustrate Colorado towns and landscape, document the place of mining in the history of Colorado and the West, and show the lives of Native Americans from more than forty tribes living west of the Mississippi River. Also included are World War II photographs of the 10th Mountain Division, ski troops based in Colorado who saw action in Italy."--Home page.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page as viewed on Mar. 21, 2002.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>

<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Frontier and pioneer life--Ohio River Valley--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Ohio River Valley--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"The First American West: The Ohio River Valley, 1750-1820 consists of 15,000 pages of original historical material documenting the land, peoples, exploration, and transformation of the trans-Appalachian West from the mid-eighteenth to the early nineteenth century. The collection is drawn from the holdings of the University of Chicago Library and the Filson Historical Society of Louisville, Kentucky. Among the sources included are books, periodicals, newspapers, pamphlets, scientific publications, broadsides, letters, journals, legal documents, ledgers and other financial records, maps, physical artifacts, and pictorial images."</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from Web page (viewed on May 3, 2002).</dc:description>

<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>

<dc:title>Slaves and the courts, 1740-1860</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Law Library.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Rare Book and Special Collections Division.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Trials--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Slavery--Law and legislation--United States--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Slavery--Law and legislation--United States--Cases.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Slavery--United States--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Presents more than a hundred pamphlets and books, published between 1772 and 1889, concerning the difficult experiences of African and African-American slaves in the American colonies and the United States. The documents, most from the Law Library and the Rare Book and Special Collections Division of the Library of Congress, comprise an assortment of trials and cases, reports, arguments, accounts, examinations of cases and decisions, proceedings, journals, a letter, and other works of historical importance. All but one of the items are available both as online images and as searchable text; the exception is an unpublished handwritten slavery code of 1860 for the District of Columbia, which is available as images only.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from Web page (viewed on Apr. 4, 2002)</dc:description>
<dc:description>"American Memory, Library of Congress."</dc:description>

Most prominently featured are the Westinghouse Air Brake Company, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, and the Westinghouse Machine Company. The films were intended to showcase the company's operations. Exterior and interior shots of the factories are shown along with scenes of male and female workers performing their duties at the plants."</dc:description>

<dc:description>Collection of over two hundred sheet music compositions on the subject of Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War. Spanning the years from Lincoln's presidential campaign in 1859 through the centenary of his birth in 1909, details historic events of late nineteenth-century America and reflects popular opinions of the time. Offers a variety of popular music styles such as Union draft songs, campaign pieces, and minstrel songs. Links to a section of The Learning Page covering the subjects of United States history, critical thinking, and arts and humanities as they relate to the collection.</dc:description>

<dc:title>The last days of a president films of McKinley and the Pan-American Exposition, 1901 /</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Motion Picture, Broadcasting, and Recorded Sound Division.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Paper Print Collection (Library of Congress)</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>McKinley, William,--1843-1901--Assassination.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>McKinley, William,--1843-1901--Death and burial.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Pan-American Exposition--(1901 :--Buffalo, N.Y.)</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Presidents--United States.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>United States--History--1901-1909.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>United States--Politics and government--1901-1909.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Presents twenty-eight films from the Paper Print Collection of the Library of Congress. Produced by the Edison Manufacturing Company from March to November 1901, these actuality motion pictures feature footage of President William McKinley at his second inauguration; the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York; McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition; and McKinley's funeral. Links to a section of The Learning Page covering the subjects of United States history, critical thinking, and arts and humanities as they relate to the collection.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from Web page (viewed on June 11, 2002).</dc:description>

<dc:coverage>United States</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:creator>Catt, Carrie Chapman, 1859-1947.</dc:creator>

<dc:subject>Women's rights--United States--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"The NAWSA Collection consists of 167 books, pamphlets and other artifacts documenting the suffrage campaign. They are a subset of the Library's larger collection donated by Carrie Chapman Catt, longtime president of the National American Woman Suffrage Association, in November of 1938. The collection includes works from the libraries of other members and officers of the organization including: Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Susan B. Anthony, Lucy Stone, Alice Stone Blackwell, Julia Ward Howe, Elizabeth Smith Miller, Mary A. Livermore."</dc:description>

<dc:title>Trails to Utah and the Pacific diaries and letters, 1846-1869 /</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Harold B. Lee Library.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Utah Academic Library Consortium.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Mormon pioneers--West (U.S.)--Diaries.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Mormon pioneers--West (U.S.)--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Pioneers--West (U.S.)--Diaries.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Pioneers--West (U.S.)--History--19th century--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Overland journeys to the Pacific--Sources.</dc:subject>

<dc:subject>West (U.S.)--History--1860-1890--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>West (U.S.)--Description and travel--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Tells the stories of Mormon families and other pioneers as they moved westward across the United States to Utah, Montana, and the Pacific between 1847 and 1869. Features forty-nine diaries, forty-three maps, eighty-two photographs and illustrations, and seven published guides for immigrants. Derived from source materials from the collections of Brigham Young University, members of the Utah Academic Libraries Consortium, and other archival institutions in Utah, Nevada, and Idaho.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from Web page (viewed on Aug. 14, 2002).</dc:description>

<dc:date>2002</dc:date>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000016</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>West (U.S.)</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:subject>Everglades (Fla.)--History.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Documents the history of the Everglades. Examines major topics and issues relating to the development, reclamation, conservation, and protection of the Everglades. Features personal correspondence and diaries, essays, manuscripts, typescripts, rare books, periodicals, scientific and engineering reports, memoranda, black and white photographs, telegrams, pamphlets, maps, color postcards, and publications from individuals and the government drawn from sixteen collections housed in the archives and special collections of the University of Miami, Florida International University, and the Historical Museum of Southern Florida.</dc:description>

<dc:subject>Chicago (Ill.)--History--1875-</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Presents images of urban life in or near Chicago, Illinois, captured on glass plate negatives between 1902 and 1933 by photographers employed by the Chicago Daily News, then one of Chicago's leading newspapers. The photographs feature a variety of topics and events covered in the newspaper as well as politicians, actors, and other prominent people who stopped in Chicago during their travels and individual athletes and sports teams who came to Chicago.</dc:description>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Prokudin-Gorskiĭ photograph collection (Library of Congress)</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Prokudin-Gorskiĭ, Sergeĭ Mikhaĭlovich, 1863-1944, photographer.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Napoleonic Wars, 1800-1815--Campaigns--Russia</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Architecture--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Art objects--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Cities & towns--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Dwellings--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Historic sites--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Industrial facilities--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Mining--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>People--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Plants--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Railroads--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Railroad construction & maintenance--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Religious articles--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Religious facilities--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Rock formations--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Villages--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Waterways--Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Asia, Central--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Europe--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Russia (Federation)--1900-1920.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Sergei Mikhailovich Prokudin-Gorskiĭ's photographic survey of the Russian Empire (1909-1915) provides 2,615 distinct photographic views that show cities and villages, religious architecture, industrial and agricultural activities and sites, historic sites, waterway and railway construction, cultural artifacts, people, and flora and fauna. Each journey is represented by one or more photographic albums and corresponding negatives for the Caucaus, Turkestan (Central Asia), Marinskii Canal, Ural Mountains region, Volga River region, Napoleonic War area, and Murmansk Railway. There is also an album of various studies, including views in Europe.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Collection title devised by Library staff.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Most photographic prints are mounted in albums compiled by Prokudin-Gorskiĭ and accompanied by his handwritten Cyrillic captions</dc:description>
<dc:description>Approximately 120 images have been digitally rendered in color, using modern techniques.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Special Collections in the Library of Congress / compiled by Annette Melville. Washington, D.C. : Library of Congress, 1980, no. 190</dc:description>
<dc:description>Educated as a chemist, Prokudin-Gorskii devoted his career to the advancement of photography. Around 1907, he formulated a plan to use the emerging technological advancements in color photography to systematically document the Russian Empire's history, culture, and modernization. Tsar Nicholas II supported this ambitious project by providing passes and transportation. Prokudin-Gorskii completed seven survey trips and conducted many illustrated lectures of his work before leaving Russia in 1918 and eventually settling in Paris.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Purchase ; photographer's sons ; 1948.</dc:description>
<dc:description>A set of catalog records describing each item is available through the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting. See http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/lcoa1.about</dc:description>
<dc:date>between 1905 and 1915</dc:date>
<dc:type>image</dc:type>
<dc:type>still image</dc:type>
<dc:type>collection</dc:type>
<dc:type>Portrait photographs</dc:type>
<dc:type>Group portraits</dc:type>
<dc:type>Glass negatives</dc:type>
<dc:type>Photographic prints</dc:type>
<dc:type>Photograph albums</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/pp.prok</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>rus</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>Asia, Central</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Europe</dc:coverage>
<dc:coverage>Russia (Federation)</dc:coverage>
<dc:rights>No known restrictions on publication. For additional information about commercial usage, see "Prokudin-Gorskii ...," [http://www.loc.gov/rr/print/res/237_prok.html]</dc:rights>
</oai_dc:dc>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>The Chinese in California 1850-1925 /</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Bancroft Library.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>University of California, Berkeley. Ethnic Studies Library</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>California Historical Society.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Chinese Americans--California--History--Sources.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"The Chinese in California, 1850-1925 illustrates nineteenth and early twentieth century Chinese immigration to California from 1850 to 1925 through about 8,000 images and pages of primary source materials. Included are photographs, original art, cartoons and other illustrations; letters, excerpts from diaries, business records, and legal documents; as well as pamphlets, broadsides, speeches, sheet music, and other printed matter. These documents describe the experiences of Chinese immigrants in California, including the nature of inter-ethnic tensions. They also document the specific contributions of Chinese immigrants to commerce and business, architecture and art, agriculture and other industries, and cultural and social life in California."</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page (viewed on Mar. 31, 2003).</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>"LC/Ameritech Award Winner"</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>Washington, DC : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2002</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/collgdc.gc000018</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

<dc:subject>Mississippi River Valley--Description and travel.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>West (U.S.)--Description and travel.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>"American Notes: Travels in America, 1750-1920 comprises 253 published narratives by Americans and foreign visitors recounting their travels in the colonies and the United States and their observations and opinions about American peoples, places, and society from about 1750 to 1920. Also included is the thirty-two-volume set of manuscript sources entitled Early Western Travels, 1748-1846, published between 1904 and 1907 after diligent compilation by the distinguished historian and secretary of the Wisconsin Historical Society Reuben Gold Thwaites."</dc:description>

<dc:coverage>West (U.S.)</dc:coverage>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Tending the commons folklife and landscape in southern West Virginia : from the American Folklife Center, Library of Congress.</dc:title>
<dc:creator>American Folklife Center.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. National Digital Library Program.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Country life--West Virginia.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Community life--West Virginia.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>West Virginia--Social life and customs.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>Features excerpts from original sound recordings and photographs from the American Folklife Center's Coal River Folklife Project (1992-99) documenting traditional uses of the mountains in southern West Virginia's Big Coal River Valley. Includes extensive interviews on native forest species and the seasonal round of traditional harvesting. Documents community cultural events such as storytelling, baptisms in the river, cemetery customs, and the spring wild leek feasts. Interpretive texts outline the social, historical, economic, environmental, and cultural contexts of community life, while a series of maps and a diagram depicting the seasonal round of community activities provide special access to collection materials.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page (viewed on Oct. 8, 2003; last updated Sept. 29 , 2000).</dc:description>
<dc:description>Offered as part of the American Memory online resource compiled by the National Digital Library Program of the Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>Washington, DC : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>[2000?]</dc:date>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/collafc.af000003</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:coverage>West Virginia</dc:coverage>
</oai_dc:dc>

<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>After the day of infamy man on the street interviews following the attack on Pearl Harbor /</dc:title>
<dc:creator>American Folklife Center.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Library of Congress. Radio Research Project.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Pearl Harbor (Hawaii), Attack on, 1941.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>World War, 1939-1945--Personal narratives, American.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>A collection of more than 12 hours of interviews recorded after the Dec. 7, 1941 bombing of Pearl Harbor and compiled from two separate audio collections: Man on the street (1941) and Dear Mr. President (1942), recorded as part of the Radio Research Project. Includes one essay: "Making and Maintaining the Original Recordings." Also included are biographies of the fieldworkers who conducted and arranged the interviews, complete transcripts of the interviews, related manuscripts, and original disc sleeves. Recordings are indexed by name, location, subject, manuscript title, and recording number. Also searchable by keyword.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Title from home page (viewed on Aug. 18, 2003).</dc:description>
<dc:publisher>Washington, D.C. : Library of Congress</dc:publisher>
<dc:date>2003</dc:date>
<dc:type>text</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/collafc.af000004</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
</oai_dc:dc>

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Aaron Copland collection,</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Copland, Aaron, 1900-1990.</dc:creator>
<dc:creator>Kraft, Victor, 1915-1976.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Copland, Aaron,--1900-1990.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Copland, Aaron,--1900-1990--Autographs.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Copland, Aaron,--1900-1990--Portraits.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Copland, Aaron,--1900-1990--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Boulanger, Nadia--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Clurman, Harold,--1901---Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Bernstein, Leonard,--1918-1990--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Bowles, Paul,--1910-1999--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Britten, Benjamin,--1913-1976--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Chávez, Carlos,--1899-1978--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Diamond, David,--1915-2005--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Harris, Roy,--1898-1979--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Ives, Charles,--1874-1954--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Reis, Claire R.--(Claire Raphael)--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Schoenberg, Arnold,--1874-1951--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Sessions, Roger,--1896-1985--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Thomson, Virgil,--1896-1989--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Musicians--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>The Aaron Copland collection consists of published and unpublished music by Copland and other composers,  correspondence, writings, biographical material, datebooks,  journals, professional papers, including legal and financial material, photographs, awards, art work, and books. Of particular interest is the correspondence with Nadia Boulanger, which extend over 50 years, and with his long-time friend, Harold Clurman. Other significant correspondents are Leonard Bernstein, Paul Bowles, Benjamin Britten, Carlos Chávez, David Diamond, Roy Harris, Charles Ives, Claire Reis, Arnold Schoenberg, Roger Sessions, and Virgil Thomson. The photographic collection of Copland's friend and confidant Victor Kraft, a professional photographer, forms part of the collection.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Cite as: Aaron Copland Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Composer Aaron Copland was born on Nov. 14, 1900, in Brooklyn, N.Y. From 1921-1924 he studied composition and orchestration with Nadia Boulanger in Paris. Copland was the recipient of the 1925-1926 Guggenheim Memorial Fellowship, the first in music. Many awards followed throughout his life. Copland performed his own music as pianist and conductor and also conducted music of other composers. He was the author of articles and books and of oral presentations on music. He was also active as an administrator, founding festivals and concert series and in publishing contemporary music. Copland died on Dec. 2, 1990, in North Tarrytown, N.Y.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Some mss. Gifts Aaron Copland ca. 1940-1970.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Bulk of the collection Gift Aaron Copland 1989.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Some mss. Gifts Nadia Boulanger estate July 18, 1980, and Mar. 6, 1981.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Libretto material for The tender land Gift Erik Johns.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Some mss. Gift Bennett Lerner.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Sound recordings and moving images transferred to Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Books from Copland's library transferred to Library of Congress Rare Book and Special Collections Division.</dc:description>
<dc:description>1154 published scores by North and South American composers (not including Copland) located in Performing Arts Library in the New York Public Library a microfilm is available in the Library of Congress Performing Arts Reading Room: Microfilm 93/20010.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Finding aid available in the Library of Congress Performing Arts Reading Room and on the Internet.</dc:description>
<dc:type>collection</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.music/eadmus.mu002006</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:rights>Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.</dc:rights>
</oai_dc:dc>

documents.resource_data:
<oai_dc:dc xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/                          http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd">
<dc:title>Irving Fine collection,</dc:title>
<dc:creator>Fine, Irving, 1914-1962.</dc:creator>
<dc:subject>Fine, Irving,--1914-1962.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Fine, Irving,--1914-1962--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Fine, Irving,--1914-1962--Autographs.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Composers--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Musicians--Portraits.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Bernstein, Leonard,--1918-1990--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Copland, Aaron,--1900-1990--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Foss, Lukas,--1922-2009--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Ginastera, Alberto,--1916-1983--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Rorem, Ned,--1923---Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:subject>Schuman, William,--1910-1992--Correspondence.</dc:subject>
<dc:description>The bulk of the materials in the collection are musical scores and sketches which represent virtually the entire musical output of the composer, some of which have been cataloged individually and classified and shelved in ML96.F47, ML96.5.F47, ML30.3C.F55, and ML29c.F527. In addition there are photographs, clippings, programs, scrapbooks, as well as correspondence from 20th century musicians such as Leonard Bernstein, Aaron Copland, Lukas Foss, Alberto Ginastera, Ned Rorem, and William Schuman.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Cite as: Irving Fine collection, Music Division, Library of Congress.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Irving Fine, American composer, teacher, and conductor, was born in Boston, Mass., on Dec. 3, 1914. He studied composition with Walter Piston at Harvard University and with Nadia Boulanger in Cambridge, Mass., and in Paris, 1France, and choral conducting with A.T. Davison, and orchestral conducting with Serge Koussevitzky. From 1939 until 1950, when he was appointed professor at Brandeis University, he also taught at Harvard. Fine was chairman of the Brandeis School of Creative Arts and served on the composition staff of the Tanglewood Music Center (formerly the Berkshire Music Center). He received two Guggenheim Fellowships, a Fulbright Research Fellowship for France, and many other awards. In addition to his composing, Fine wrote articles and reviews. Irving Fine died in Boston on Aug. 23, 1962.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Gifts Verna Fine 1964-1991.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Forty unpublished tapes transferred to Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division.</dc:description>
<dc:description>Finding aid available in the Library of Congress Performing Arts Reading Room and on the Internet.</dc:description>
<dc:type>collection</dc:type>
<dc:identifier>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.music/eadmus.mu001001</dc:identifier>
<dc:language>eng</dc:language>
<dc:rights>Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.</dc:rights>
</oai_dc:dc>
